node.title: Getting non-nodal values to output with nodal values in same .csv or vice versa
node.bodyText:
I currently use VectorPostprocessors to output some of my nodal variables to a .csv file. I want my output to have a variable per each node and timestep. However, I also want to output an elemental variable for each node.
My elemental variable must stay elemental as it is part of the discrete nucleation kernel and has to be an elemental auxiliary variable. Is there a way to get nucl_map to output with the vectorpostprocessors? Like an average of the elemental values per node? I looked at the DiscreteNucleatoinData post-processor. I provided some code below. Thank you so much for your help! Let me know if you need more information.
[AuxVariables]
  [./nucl_map]
     order = first
     family = MONOMIAL
     outputs = exodus
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./nucl_map_aux]
    type = DiscreteNucleationAux
    map = map
    variable = nucl_map
    no_nucleus_value = 0
    nucleus_value = 1
  [../]
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
    [./etarad]
    type = NodalValueSampler
    variable = 'etab0 etam0'
    sort_by = 'id'
  [../] 
[] 

I also wouldn't mind the nodal variables being ouputed per element either I just wanted the data synced.

You could project the elemental variable on a nodal one with the ProjectionAux, then output that one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/ProjectionAux.html

node.title: StochasticTools; report input/sampled values sent to sub-app
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am using StochasticTools module for a monte carlo run as part of a UQ workflow. Using the StochasticReporter returns the final QoIs in the json file, but I am wondering if it is possible to also save the input parameters from the sampler which are sent to the sub-app to produce each QoI?
For example, the reporter and transfer
[Reporters]
  [storage]
    type = StochasticReporter
    parallel_type = ROOT
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [sub]
    type = SamplerParameterTransfer
    to_multi_app = sub
    sampler = train_sampler_a
    parameters = 'Functions/slope_tc/value'
    check_multiapp_execute_on = false
  []
  [data]
    type = SamplerReporterTransfer
    from_multi_app = sub
    sampler = train_sampler_a
    stochastic_reporter = storage
    from_reporter = 'temp_xmin_wall/value'
  []
[]

yields the following output:
    "time_steps": [
        {
            "storage": {
                "data:converged": [
                    true,
                    true,
                    true,
                    true,
                    true,
                    true,
                    true,
                    true,
                    true,
                    true
                ],
                "data:temp_xmin_wall:value": [
                    327.21460091191886,
                    327.22095318699365,
                    327.2186406333933,
                    327.2131752782587,
                    327.2159796106987,
                    327.2169546408685,
                    327.2155865311054,
                    327.2214386771292,
                    327.21889294080415,
                    327.2142013147521
                ]
            },
            "time": 1.0,
            "time_step": 1
        }
    ]

and would like to have an extra dict entry for each property in [Distributions].
Best wishes
Josh

@grmnptr @somu15
I don't see an option but it seems a good idea to me
You may use SamplerData VPP. See moose/modules/stochastic_tools/test/tests/samplers/monte_carlo/monte_carlo_weibull.i as an example.

Got it, thanks!
FYI, this did not add anything to the json file. But when I set csv = true in [Outputs], I get a csv file with the sampler data and another with the StochasticReporter output, which I prefer.

For others,
I think there s an option in outputs to convert VPP output to reporter output, to use json
Yes, only reporter objects output to json. Try if https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/reporters/StochasticMatrix.html works.

node.title: Reactive transport couplings Errors
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Community,
I've been working with the transport reactive model located in the folder '/moose/modules/combined/examples/geochem-porous_flow' and have developed my own models, porous_flow.i and aquifer_chemistry.i.
To couple these models, I utilized 'MultiApps'. However, I encountered a 'parallel-communicated exception' error once the simulation reached t > 100,000s.

You can access the models via the following links:
Google drive: (https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1NrCVzYxLryaYVuvoumjBkrbedpDhcKFY?usp=sharing)
Github:(https://github.com/robo-boluo/Module_test.git)
I would greatly appreciate any guidance or assistance with this issue.
Robo

Hello
It is odd that a failed solve ended the calculation. We now rely on exceptions so that a failed solve triggers a second attempt with a smaller time step.
You can perform this manually with a checkpoint. You create a checkpoint in your first simulation, and restart from it with a smaller time step.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/outputs/Checkpoint.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/restart_recover.html
While I see that the nested geochemistry solve time step was properly reduced to try to find convergence, I think the time step of the main-app & multiapp iteration can be reduced as well.
@rpodgorney @1runer
Guillaume

node.title: Enforcing initial velocity of beam
node.bodyText:
As a first step to a more complex simulation, I'd like to do a transient simulation of an Euler-Bernoulli beam with the beam having a nonzero initial velocity. I saw this question here #26111 and followed the advice of maxnezdyur. I tried TIMESTEP_END and LINEAR as the execute_on option for NewmarkVelAux. Following the first example here, I set the initial condition as
[ICs]
  [vel_y_ic]
    type = FunctionIC
    variable = vel_y
    function = vel_y_ic_fun
    block = 0
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [vel_y_ic_fun]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '0.01*x'
  []
[]

I used the following post processor code to debug the problem
[Postprocessors]
  [disp_x]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1.6 0.0 0.0'
    variable = disp_x
  []
  [disp_y]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1.6 0.0 0.0'
    variable = disp_y
  []
  [vel_y_1b]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0.0 0.0 0.0'
    variable = vel_y
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
  []
  [vel_y_2b]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0.8 0.0 0.0'
    variable = vel_y
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
  []
  [vel_y_3b]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1.6 0.0 0.0'
    variable = vel_y
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_BEGIN
  []
  [vel_y_1e]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0.0 0.0 0.0'
    variable = vel_y
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [vel_y_2e]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0.8 0.0 0.0'
    variable = vel_y
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [vel_y_3e]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1.6 0.0 0.0'
    variable = vel_y
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  []
  [accel_y]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1.6 0.0 0.0'
    variable = accel_y
  []
[]

the output is
Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+
| time           | accel_y        | disp_x         | disp_y         | vel_y_1b       | vel_y_1e       | vel_y_2b       | vel_y_2e       | vel_y_3b       | vel_y_3e       |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+
|   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |
|   1.000000e-02 |  -6.400000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   8.000000e-03 |  -8.000000e-03 |   1.600000e-02 |  -1.600000e-02 |
|   2.000000e-02 |   1.280000e+01 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |  -8.000000e-03 |   8.000000e-03 |  -1.600000e-02 |   1.600000e-02 |
|   3.000000e-02 |  -1.920000e+01 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   0.000000e+00 |   8.000000e-03 |  -8.000000e-03 |   1.600000e-02 |  -1.600000e-02 |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+

It can be seen that the initial condition for vel_y is actually only appied for the beginning of the 2nd timestep, the one starting at t=0.01s. Why is that? How can I fix it?
Many thanks,
Felix

Ok, what I just managed to understand is that the way I set up the problem, it cannot work. By computing the velocities and the accelerations using NewmarkVelAux and NewmarkAccelAux, it always uses the previous displacements, velocities and accelerations and the new displacements to compute the new velocities and accelerations. Importantly, the new displacements are computed independently. Hence, the information about the initial velocities, that I supplied, never enters the computation of the displacements. The computation of the velocities and displacements is purely driven by the computation of the displacements. There is no coupling between them.
Ok, I found this explanation here about the dynamics for solid mechanics. I added InertialForceBeam to my model and while there still seem to be some issues, my beam is oscillating :)

node.title: Inquiry Regarding Automated Termination of Simulation Based on Runtime Threshold
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Forum Members,
I hope this message finds you well. I am currently seeking assistance regarding the automatic termination of simulations when the runtime exceeds a specified threshold.
I have been utilizing PerfGraphData to acquire runtime information and subsequently employing Terminator to set termination conditions in my input file, as demonstrated below:
[UserObjects]
  [./term]
    type = Terminator
    expression = 'run_time > 600'
  [../]
[]
[Postprocessors]
...
  [./run_time]
    type = PerfGraphData
    section_name = "Root"
    data_type = total
  [../]
...
[./]
However, I have encountered an issue where Terminator and PerfGraphData only execute at the beginning or end of a timestep, rather than terminating the simulation once the overall runtime exceeds a certain threshold. Therefore, my inquiry is whether there exists a method or condition to automatically terminate the simulation when it reaches a specified runtime threshold, such as after 10 minutes of computation.
The reason behind my quest for this functionality is that in the simulations I have created, the output continuously displays "Computing Residual," as illustrated below:
Time Step 8, time = 0.108816, dt = 0.020736

Grain Tracker Status:
Grains active index 0: 1 -> 1
Grains active index 1: 1 -> 1

Finished inside of GrainTracker

    Computing Residual............................................................................................................................................

However, attempts to terminate the program using ctrl + c or killall have been unsuccessful in generating *.prof files. On the contrary, the automatic termination of the simulation has successfully generated *.prof files.
I would greatly appreciate any insights or suggestions on how to achieve automated termination based on a runtime threshold.
Thank you for your time and assistance.
Best regards,
Wei

Hello
The default execution schedule for these objects is at the end of every time step
You ll want to specify execute_on of LINEAR to have them execute much more often. Then they can stop the simulation at any linear iteration (when computing the residual in reality)
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
Now I followed your suggestion of doing it during the linear step, but it still doesn't work, as it turns out that our challenge is that when the simulation gets stuck at "Compute Residuals............", we can't do the linear step ends.
To solve this problem, I think it is crucial to ensure that the program gracefully catches the interrupt signal and performs the necessary cleanup and save operations before exiting. However, this seems to involve modifying the main() function.
I will keep you updated on any developments. If you have any insights I'd be grateful for your input.
Sincerely,
Wei

The interrupt signal is gracefully caught already, it s just that the Terminator is only emitting it when it is executed
And seemingly it does not get executed. Or not yet.

Yes, the Terminator is only executed when it evaluates the expression = 'run_time > 600', so the Terminator cannot be called when the simulation gets stuck at 'Compute Residuals............'.
Therefore, can the simulation program perform the necessary cleanup and save operations before exiting when Ctrl+C is executed?
By the way, if I set execute_on=CUSTOM, can I customize the behavior of the terminator to trigger when the real-time running time of the simulation reaches a certain threshold?

execute_on=CUSTOM will still require a place somewhere in the code where you will put _problem.execute(EXEC_CUSTOM). So unless you know a good place within computeResidual (but I expect it's taking long because the mesh is large and simply computeQpResidual on every kernel is taking a lot of time?), it won't work

Therefore, can the simulation program perform the necessary cleanup and save operations before exiting when Ctrl+C is executed?

No we don't have code to catch SIGINT or SIGSTP in moose. So we would not properly stop the simulation.
However I dont know that you need this to profile? Did you try? Maybe you can profile even without a clean program termination

Hi @GiudGiud,
Thank you for your efforts. This problem has been solved by setting signal_received to accept the Ctrl + C signal and the execute mooseError. The simulation can then perform the operation of saving the performance report file.
Sincerely,
Wei

If possible, please refrain from posting pictures of text. It prevents others from searching for things like "Advancing State" and landing on posts which may be solved.
NotePosting Guidlines

Thanks, I just editted.
@GiudGiud what could be the problem? it seems the issue is related to advancing the state of the FE problem by copying old solutions, shifting material properties and updating stateful material properties for the next time step etc, right? but why it stucks there? what could be the reason?
Thanks,
Rahim
how many aux variables did you have?

@GiudGiud
I had 17, then i removed 4 of them.

node.title: Question about symmetric boundary condition setting of thermal stress calculation of a 1/8 rotational symmetric model
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts:
I simulated a 1/8 rotational symmetric solid mechanical problem, but ran into following question:
Precondition:
I've simulated a thermal conduction problem using this symmetric model, and got temperature distribution, which I was about to use for thermal stress calculation
My setting:
I set zero normal-displacement on  both symmetric surfaces like:
$$\vec{n}\bullet\vec{disp}=0\ \ \Rightarrow\ \ n_x{disp}_x+n_y{disp}_y=0$$
And I used MatchValueBC for realizing this:

Result:
There seems still normal displacement on symmetric surface:

Where white block is original model, and wireframe is displaced geometry, two green lines stands for original symmetric surface.
And I've plotted displacement of symmetry surface:

Where Result is
$$n_x{disp}_x+n_y{disp}_y$$
and doesn't equal to 0.
Question
It seems my symmetric boundary condition didn't work. What might be the reason for this?
Or if there's other way to set this kind of symmetric boundary condition?
Thanks! (Sorry I can only provide relative photos rather than relative input files, cause I ran this example on a LAN computer)

Hello
If you are not using parallel processing you can use the Functor system (the functor APIs on a variable) to tie the values on the top surface to the values on the bottom one.
You can use an ElemPointArg and specify the point analytically to go from one surface to the other
You can keep trying on constrainting the displacement on a single surface by writing a penalty version of this BC
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume, thanks for reply, while it's hard for me to fully understand your suggestion, I might need to learn Functor system better.
But I still wonder what's wrong with my settings by using MatchValueBC, could you help me point out the problem?

I dont know.
Did you double check those two coefficients?
Do you get a converged result on every time step? What does the simulation log look like?

I check those coefficients, and the calculation did converge with relative tolerance below than1e-10.
Besides I refine the mesh but same strange result.

are rel_fuel1 / 2 both exactly on the outer surface? sometimes the mesher will place nodes inside the volume in a nodeset
have you tried using approaches from the solid mechanics module? I m thinking they have more custom techniques for this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/PenaltyInclinedNoDisplacementBC.html

I will try to find more relevant from Solid Mechanics module.
Thanks again for your suggestions!

node.title: Phase field and Crystal plasticity
node.bodyText:
Hello Experts,
I am currently trying to impose a crystal plasticity model in a two-phase problem. There is one example file-kks_mechanics_VTS.i which calculates elastic stresses for each phases using base_name input parameter.
The materials I am using, require crystal plasticity, and also the ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticity stress has this base_name option. Could anyone help me with writing the code using base_name for the multiphase problem or help me find an example from MOOSE of how to use that?

node.title: Is there a Porous Flow Master Action System
node.bodyText:
Dear Community,
Is there something like the "Tensor Mechanics Master Action System" (link) for porous flow?
Thanks for your help.

hello
I think there's this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/actions/PoroMechanicsAction.html
Guillaume

Dear @GiudGiud,
Thanks for the quick answer. Unfortunately, the docu on PoroMechanicsAction is still under construction and I fail to find an example where this action is used within [Physics]. Preferably in combination with [SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]. I only find a "PoroMechanics"-Action used inside a kernel here.
Do you know if there is such an example available?
[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
    [./all]
      add_variables = true
      ...
    []
  []
  [PoroMechanics]
      ?????
  []
[]

The [Physics] syntax is currently being rolled out.
We have not gotten to PoroMechanics. In fact, Poromechanics being nested under Kernels rather than Modules/PorousFlow makes me think it hasn't been transitioned to the previously preferred syntax either. So you wont find an example with the [Physics] syntax for a while

node.title: Simulating excavation or construction in time
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
in the analysis of geotechnical problems, often I have to simulate an excavation or construction process. Due to non linearity, either processes need to be spread over a number of analysis increments.
A typical approach to the excavation problem involves:

removing elements and constraint the nodes at the new boundary (or apply nodal forces at the new boundary so that equilibrium is not altered)
incrementally reduce the reaction forces at the boundary to zero.

For construction:

activate new elements
incrementally change the material stiffness and gravity of the new elements from zero to the final value

I've found that elements can be removed or added to the analysis domain through e.g.:
CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
but is there any predefined way to do this "slowly" over a certain number of steps?
Best,

Hello
While the process of changing an element from a subdomain to another is abrupt (as soon as the threshhold is passed), you can create BCs/material properties that depend continuously on the threshold or another variable to ramp the other quantities slower.
I would use something like max(0, variable - threshold value) / (max_variable_value -  threshold value) as a multiplier
Guillaume

Hello, can you tell me the use 'CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier' can simulate filling process? If possible, could you please provide more detailed instructions? It would be nice to have an example. Thank you for your help.

Hello
you premesh the volume that will be filled, and you change its subdomain as the filling happens from an inactive subdomain (a subdomain with no equations) to an active one.
i think there are other posts with examples. There should be an app that has been developed to do this. @1runer do you know if that’s true?
Thank you for your reply. I want to zero the displacement calculated in the first step and then proceed to the next calculation, is there any good way to do it?

Hello
You can only clear a variable using either a new simulation in which you do not restart that variable
Or you use a multiapp and set up a transfer that sends 0 values to that variable
Guillaume
Hello, Can I remove deformations only in part of the location? For example, the grid is divided into blocks 1 and 2, and the calculation continues after the deformation of block 2 is removed.
